citation.abstract:
Nasal colonization has gained attention as effect modifier in S. aureus vaccine trials, suggesting interference of carriage with T-cell immunity. Likewise, T-cell signals may be involved in regulating effectors of epithelial innate defense.
 Whole blood of 43 persistent and 49 non-carriers was stimulated with viable S. aureus Th1/Th2/Th17 cytokine expression was measured, compared between carrier groups, and linked with data on human beta-defensin-3 (hBD-3) mRNA in skin while adjusting for transcriptionally relevant promotor haplotypes.
 Compared to carriers, stimulated whole blood of non-carriers contained on average 60% more IFN-γ mRNA (P=0.031) and 19% less IL-17 mRNA (P=0.11), resulting in an on average 90% higher IFN-γ/IL-17A mRNA ratio (P=0.003). In a multivariable model, per duplication of mRNA template, the risk of being a carrier increased by 93% for IL-17A (OR 1.93, 95% confidence interval 1.10-3.41, P=0.023) and decreased by 35% for IFN-γ (0.65, 0.47-0.91, P=0.01). Independent of carriage and DEFB promotor haplotype, one unit increase in IFN-γ/IL17A mRNA ratio (mean 5.93; SD 1.60) led to a 24% increase in hBD-3 transcription in experimentally wounded human skin (P=0.003).
 A low Th1/Th17 mRNA ratio increases the propensity for persistent S. aureus nasal colonization, with downregulated hBD-3 transcription providing a potential link.
citation.title:
The ratio of Th1 to Th17 cytokines in whole blood is associated with human β-defensin-3 expression in skin and persistent
              Staphylococcus aureus
              nasal carriage
